results.title: Sing yourself silly!
results.brief_description: Big Bird and his friends invite you to have some silly fun with eleven of their favourite silly songs. Sing along with Ernie, Oscar the Grouch, Hoots the Owl and other Sesame Street favourites. Includes a song-lyric poster.

results.title: Sing of the border
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films, Edgar H. Anstey and Tony Thompson
results.brief_description: The songs of the Scottish border country are more than just folk songs. They are the history of a people. Families fought for power along the border, and the ballads have preserved their names and deeds. Although battles have passed, the country and the pattern of life remain much the same today.

results.title: Sing and be happy with Jane Pickens
results.brief_description: A musical sing-along with Jane Pickens (with audience participation and bouncing ball). Songs include: ‘I’ll be walking with my honey’, ‘I never knew’, and ‘I’ll see you in my dreams’.

results.title: Sing a little
results.brief_description: Illustrates a Canadian Broadcasting Company radio session of which Allan Mills is compere. Three songs are presented: “The Farmer’s cursed wife” whom even the devil wouldn’t keep; “Barbara Allen”; and “Jack the sailor” who was swallowed by a whale. Animated puppets enact the story told by each song.

results.title: Sine Curve
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Donald Batchelor
results.brief_description: Discusses the sine funtion. Illustrates familiar periodic motions and uses models to analyse the nature of a wave motion and to show how a sine curve can be drawn. From the series “Visions in mathematics”.

results.title: Since I Left You – The Avalanches
results.brief_description: Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling, The Avalanches’ ‘Since I Left You’ manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.

constellations_primary.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_primary.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

results.description: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. Directed by Rob Leggatt and Leigh Marling from the Blue Source art collective, it manages to combine familiar pop culture touchstones like Flashdance (1983) with the utterly surreal as two miners burrow through a black and white world into full colour.
description_for_label: It seems fitting that for a band with such an unusual musical reputation like The Avalanches, the accompanying visuals to ‘Since I Left You’ would be so unique as well. results.title: Sinatra: portrait of an album
results.brief_description: An inside studio view of an album being produced by the singing legend Frank Sinatra in collaboration with the talented musician and arranger, Quincy Jones. This fascinating documentary provides interviews and commentary by those involved in helping to create the album “L.A. is my lady” including lyricists Alan and Marilyn Bergman, producer Phil Ramone, and musicians Lionel Hampton, George Benson, Frank Foster and Steve Gadd. Also features a cameo appearance and personal commentary by a youthful Michael Jackson. Describes the tension and electricity that comes with the energetic and demanding Sinatra and the mutual admiration and respect the singer and the musicians have for each other.

results.title: Sinatra: a passionate life
results.brief_description: Sinatra: A passionate life is a loving tribute to the late Frank Sinatra. It provides an excellent biographical overview of the singer, actor and all-round performer, ranging from his childhood years to retirement. We are introduced to Sinatra’s family, his place of birth, his admiration for Bing Crosby, his initial rise to fame, his huge success during World War II, his work in the film and TV industries, his Vegas years and experience with the Brat Pack, and so on. Interviews with numerous colleagues and close friends are interweaved with archival footage, photos and film excerpts. The archival footage is especially splendid including such rare and classic moments as Sinatra and Elvis Presley on live television performing each other’s songs or Dean Martin and Sammy Davis Jnr carrying out their legendary Brat Pack routines at the Sands casino in Las Vegas. Though completed just prior to Sinatra’s passing, “Sinatra: A passionate life” is overall both a fitting testament to the man’s unique talent, career achievements and influence and a record of the eras in which he performed.
